citation.article-title: Clostridium frigidicarnis sp. nov., a psychrotolerant bacterium associated with 'blown pack' spoilage of vacuum-packed meats.

p.s: Description of Clostridium frigidicarnis sp. nov.
Clostridium frigidicarnis (fri.gi.di.car'nis. L. adj. frigidus cool; L. n. carno meat; N.L. gen. n. frigidicarnis of cool meat)

Colonies on sheep blood agar measure from 2.2-7.2 mm in diameter and are: circular to irregular; with undulate, lobate or erose margins; creamy-grey to grey; opaque or semi-opaque to translucent; and phaemolytic.
Cells are Gram-positive, motile rods (4.5-9.4 μm long and 1.3-1.6 μm wide) occurring singly or in pairs.
Elliptical spores are produced in early stationary growth phase.
Psychrotolerant and grows between 3-8 and 40.5°C (optimum growth temperature is 30.0-38.5°C).
At 30°C, it grows between pH 4.7 and 9.5; optimum pH for growth is 6.4-7.2.
Fructose, glucose, mannose, mannitol and trehalose are fermented, lecithinase activity is present and gelatin is hydrolysed.
Fermentation products formed in PYGS broth are acetate, ethanol, butyrate, isovalerate, butanol, isobutyrate, oxalacetate, lactate, hydrogen and carbon dioxide.
Major CFA are myristic, palmitic and oleic acids.
Isolated from vacuum-packed temperature-abused beef and from faeces, hides and tonsils of bovine slaughter stock.
Possibly forms a part of a normal flora of vacuum-packed chilled meats.
The type strain is strain SPL77AT (=DSM 12271T).
